advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''<br> ''Now, go !''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £99 IN JANUARY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (APR. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing: an era comes to the end" <br><br> "The Sirius era begins"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A rainbow in your office"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Enter the game of computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD APRIL 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The personal computer at the top of its form.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGA POSTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The personal computer of Mr sales manager"</blockquote>

computer.cpu: TI TMS 9900 (with 256 bytes 'cache', actually it accesses to 256 bytes of RAM)
computer.description:
This TI99/4A all plastic beige version was launched in June 1983, five months before Texas Instruments decide to definitely get out of the home computers market.
The goal was to reduce the production costs and offer a better price front of the Commodore VIC-20 competition. T.I. also thought of standardizing colours and peripherals of its future line of home computers, the TI99/2 and TI99/8.
Internal hardware of the beige version was quite the same as the TI99/4 black and silver model. All of the TI99 peripherals could run on the new version. Some minor change were made though: ? New power supply unit ? New power switch moved to to right of the keyboard ? The power Led was replaced with a blue colored area on the power switch ? Only the T.I. licencied ROM cartridges could run on this version.
Despite its short life, several tens of thousands system were sold, in American continent and Australia.

emulator.description: Emulates all of the TI-99 versions, including the Geneve card
emulator.name: Mess emulator

emulator.description: Open Source & freeware TI-99/4A emulator for Windows 9x
emulator.name: Classic99

emulator.description: Win994a is a TI-99/4A simulator written by Cory Burr that installs and runs in Windows
emulator.name: Win994a

emulator.description: MacV9T9 is a TI99 emulator for the Macintosh
emulator.name: MacV9T9 official homepage

computer.graphics: Multicolor mode : 48 x 64 with 16 colors256 x 192 with 16 colors (only accesed via machine code)Sprites (only with TI-Extended Basic)
computer.keyboard: QWERTY full-stroke keyboard, 48 keys2 x SHIFT, CTRL, ALPHA LOCK, FCTN
computer.name: TI 99 / 4A Beige
computer.ports: Tape interface, RGB video, Joystick (2), cartridge slot (Solid State Cartridge)
computer.ram: 256 bytes - Memory expansion card can be added : 4 KB or 32 KB (up to 52 KB)
computer.rom: 26 KB? : 8 KB ROM connected to the CPU + 18 KB ROM in byte-serial bit-mapped circuits (usually known as GROM, Graphic Only Memory)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opened system seen from the bottom side.<br> A metallic magnetic shield covers the motherboard.<br> At least two different power regulator circuits <b>(1)</b> and keyboards <b>(2)</b> were used. Some of them came from Japan.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> RGB video output DIN plug<br> <b>(2)</b> TMS 9918A video processor<br> <b>(3)</b> TMS 9901 I/O management chip<br> <b>(4)</b> TMS 9900 16-bit processor<br> <b>(5)</b> 3 x GROM 6 KB chips<br> <b>(6)</b> Sound generator chip (Texas 76494)<br> <b>(7)</b> ROM cartridges connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Tape recorder DB9 connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Extension connector<br> <b>(10)</b> 256 bytes Static RAM chips (2 x Motorola 6810)<br> <b>(11)</b> 8 KB system ROM chip (Texas CD3227)<br> <b>(12)</b> Power leads<br> <b>(13)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(14)</b> 16 KB RAM chips (8 x 4116)<br> <b>(15)</b> Joystick DB9 connector</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Extension connector<br> • Tape recorder DB9 plug<br> • Power plug. Power is supplied by and external mono or dual voltage PSU, depending on versions<br> • RGB video out DIN plug</blockquote>

computer.sound: 3 channels, 5 octaves (110hz to 55khz) and 1 noise channel (periodic and white)
